contentrichtext.text: {{Wiktionary|Ν|ν}} {{Greek Alphabet|letter=nu}} '''Nu''' {{IPAc-en|nj|uː}} (uppercase '''Ν''' lowercase '''ν''', also transcribed ''Ny''; modern {{Lang-el|Νι}} {{IPA-el|ni|}} Ni), is the 13th letter of the [[Greek alphabet]]. In the system of [[Greek numerals]] it has a value of 50. It is derived from the [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician letter]] nun [[Image:Phoenician nun.svg|20px]]. Its [[Latin script|Latin]] equivalent is N, though the lowercase resembles the Roman lowercase [[v]]. The name of the letter is written {{lang|grc|{{Unicode|νῦ}}}} in [[Ancient Greek]] and traditional [[Modern Greek]] [[polytonic orthography]], while in [[Modern Greek]] it is written {{lang|el|νι}} {{IPA|[ni]}}. The lower-case letter ν is used as a symbol for: * [[Degrees of freedom (statistics)|Degree of freedom]] in [[statistics]]. * The [[frequency]]<ref>See e.g. [[Planck constant|Planck's formula]]</ref> of a wave in physics and other fields; sometimes also [[spatial frequency]]. * The [[specific volume]] in [[thermodynamics]]. * [[Viscosity#Kinematic_viscosity:_.CE.BD_.3D_.CE.BC_.2F_.CF.81|Kinematic viscosity]] in [[fluid mechanics]]. * [[Poisson's ratio]], the ratio of strains perpendicular with and parallel with an applied force. * Any of three kinds of [[neutrino]] in particle physics. * One of [[Greeks (finance)|the Greeks]] in [[mathematical finance]], known as "vega". * The number of [[neutrons]] released per [[nuclear fission|fission]] of an atom in nuclear physics. * A [[DNA polymerase]] found in higher [[eukaryotes]] and implicated in Translesion Synthesis. * Molecular vibrational mode, ν<sub>x</sub> where x is the number of the vibration (a label). * The [[stoichiometric coefficient]]. * The [[Greatest fixed point]] of a function, as commonly used in the [[Mu calculus|μ-calculus]]. * The maximum conditioning possible for an [[unconditioned stimulus]] in the [[Rescorla-Wagner model]]. * The [[true anomaly]], it is an angular parameter that defines the position of a body moving along an orbit, see [[orbital elements]]. ==Character Encodings== * Greek Nu / Coptic Ni<ref>Unicode Code Charts: [http://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U0370.pdf Greek and Coptic (Range: 0370-03FF)]</ref> {{charmap |039D|name1=Greek Capital Letter Nu |03BD|name2=Greek Small Letter Nu |2C9A|name3=Coptic Capital Letter Ni |2C9B|name4=Coptic Small Letter Ni |map2=DOS Greek|map2char1=8C|map2char2=A4 |map3=DOS Greek-2|map3char1=B5|map3char2=E7 |map4=Windows 1253|map4char1=CD|map4char2=ED |namedref1=TeX|ref1char2=\nu }} * Mathematical Nu {{charmap |1D6B4|name1=Mathematical Bold<br />Capital Nu |1D6CE|name2=Mathematical Bold<br />Small Nu |1D6EE|name3=Mathematical Italic<br />Capital Nu |1D708|name4=Mathematical Italic<br />Small Nu |1D728|name5=Mathematical Bold Italic<br />Capital Nu |1D742|name6=Mathematical Bold Italic<br />Small Nu }} {{charmap |1D762|name1=Mathematical Sans-Serif<br />Bold Capital Nu |1D77C|name2=Mathematical Sans-Serif<br />Bold Small Nu |1D79C|name3=Mathematical Sans-Serif<br />Bold Italic Capital Nu |1D7B6|name4=Mathematical Sans-Serif<br />Bold Italic Small Nu }} These characters are used only as mathematical symbols. Stylized Greek text should be encoded using the normal Greek letters, with markup and formatting to indicate text style. == See also == * [[Movable nu]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nu (Letter)}} [[Category:Greek letters]]
